title: How to survive a glaciation: the challenge of estimating biologically realistic potential distributions under freezing conditions
abstract: Correlative ecological niche models are increasingly used to estimate potential distributions during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) for biogeographical research. In the case of presence-background/pseudoabsences techniques, cold environments that are poorly represented in existing geography can complicate the process of model calibration and transfer into more extreme cold environments that were very common during the LGM (non-analog conditions). This may lead to biologically unrealistic estimations. Using one cold-adapted North American mammal, we explore a real scenario to better understand the effect of restricting the range of environmental conditions over which niche models are calibrated and then transferred to LGM conditions. We performed two sets of experiments in Maxent: 1) we calibrated models in the context of only present-day climate conditions, which is the most common practice, and compared predictions under LGM conditions based on two extrapolation methods (clamping versus unconstrained); 2) we calibrated single models using both present-day and LGM conditions as part of the same background in order to include more extreme environments in the model calibration. Our experiments led to dramatically different estimates of species' potential distributions, showing notable differences with respect to latitudinal and elevational shifts during the LGM. Models calibrated using present-day climates yielded biologically unrealistic estimations, suggesting that species survived in the glaciers during the LGM. Even more unrealistic estimations were achieved when clamping was enforced as the method to extrapolate. Models calibrated in the context of both modern and past climates reduced the required degree of extrapolation and allowed more realistic potential distributions, suggesting that the species avoided extremely cold conditions during the LGM. This study alerts to the possibility of obtaining implausible potential distributions during the LGM due to restricted background datasets and offers recommendations that should promote better strategies to estimate distributional changes during glaciations.

body_text.text: Expanded continental and alpine glaciers during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM, ~21 000 yr before present) were the result of colder conditions than today across the world (Ehlers et al. 2011) . Several species shifted ranges toward lower latitudes or elevations in response to extreme cold conditions (Davis and Shaw 2001) . These distributional shifts, coupled with subsequent warming, had consequences throughout the species' distributions, such as the fragmentation and isolation of populations, reduction of range size, local extinction and the need to persist in refugia for subsequent recolonizations. For this reason, considerable attention has focused on this major glaciation in order to better understand species' current distributional patterns (Peterson 2009) .

Correlative ecological niche models are becoming widely used to estimate climate-driven species' potential distributions during glacial periods. These predictions have the potential to graphically inform about range shifts that likely occurred during these episodes, which have been useful for testing evolutionary hypotheses about the forces shaping the current patterns of genetic and phenotypic variation (Graham 1986 , Carnaval et al. 2009 , Elith and Leathwick 2009 . Maxent (Phillips et al. 2006) has come to be one of the most commonly used algorithms (Booth et al. 2014) . It relies on the comparison of environments of sites where species occur with the range of environmental conditions presented across the study area (Elith et al. 2010) . The environmental variation available across the study area, typically referred to as the background, is crucial to characterize the response curves for each predictor variable (Merow et al. 2013) . A widely used strategy to generate this background is to sample conditions within the area that has been accessible to the species via dispersal over relevant time periods (Barve et al. 2011) , avoiding areas where species may be absent for reasons other than unsuitable climatic conditions (Anderson and Raza 2010) .

When the environments are poorly represented in the background sampled within those areas, however, they may fail to characterize response curves to predictor variables, which is especially problematic if the model prediction goes beyond the range of environments used to calibrate the model (i.e. model extrapolation into non-analog conditions; Thuiller et al. 2004 , VanDerWal et al. 2008 , Veloz et al. 2012 . If a geographic prediction is required for areas holding these non-analog conditions, the model should extrapolate the response curves. In the case of reconstructed distributions during the LGM, this issue is particularly relevant since the calibration of the model usually does not include extremely cold environments like those that existed during the ice age. If the niche model is transferred into the LGM when cold conditions were more common than in the present, then the prediction will depend on how the response curves are extrapolated into these non-analog conditions, which is hazardous and may not guarantee a biologically realistic prediction (Hirzel and Le Lay 2008 , Fitzpatrick and Hargrove 2009 , Nogués-Bravo 2009 , Guevara et al. 2018a ).

Maxent offers two options for extrapolating into nonanalog conditions: 1) holding or 'clamping' the response constant to the modeled suitability value at the point of truncation, which is the default option in this algorithm, or 2) allowing the model to estimate the response without any constraint (Elith et al. 2010) . Explicit comparisons to assess which extrapolation method is most appropriate to predict into non-analog LGM conditions have been largely overlooked (Guevara et al. 2018a) . Another way to deal with the problem of non-analog conditions is to capture a wider environmental range of species to calibrate models, characterizing the whole of the response curve and reducing the need to extrapolate (Thuiller et al. 2004 ). An example of how the range of environmental conditions can be increased is using a multi-temporal calibration approach, which can capture the different set of climatic conditions that a species has been exposed to over time (e.g. through the Quaternary; Nogués-Bravo 2009).

Identifying the most appropriate strategy to estimate potential distributions under LGM conditions is urgently necessary to better understand the effect of climate change on changes in the distribution of species. Here we estimated the current and LGM potential distribution of the American pika, (Ochotonidae, Ochotona princeps), to assess 1) whether choosing an appropriate extrapolation method or 2) whether calibrating models using present-day and LGM climates pooled together as part of the same background can lead to more biologically realistic potential distributions because artificial truncation of response curves could be avoided. To corroborate model outputs, we used paleoecological, ecophysiological, and genetic evidence to allow us to make clear predictions for each of the study species.

We focus on the American pika as a case study, a coldadapted mammal that lives on the edge of cold conditions, due to the natural restriction imposed by geography (Fig. 1) . The American pika occurs from close to sea level to about 4000 m, but its elevational distribution varies with latitude. Pikas are typically found in relatively cool and moist montane habitats (Hafner and Smith 2010) . The species has a widespread but discontinuous geographic distribution throughout mountainous areas of the western United States and southwestern Canadian provinces (Smith and Weston 1990) . In this region, high mountains and low intermountain basins were deeply influenced by cold-dry conditions corresponding to the LGM, with continental ice sheets engulfing areas in more northern latitudes (> 48°N in western Unites States, Ehlers et al. 2011) . Fossil data suggest that pika populations occupied lower elevations and latitudes during the LGM (Hafner 1993) , and genetic evidence indicates that the most northern populations are the result of postglacial expansions (Galbreath et al. 2009) . Consequently, an ecologically credible niche model for the American pika projected to conditions for the LGM should predict areas at high elevation and latitude to be unsuitable.

Occurrence data for Ochotona princeps were downloaded from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF; search available at <https://doi.org/10.15468/dl.xlit62>, downloaded on 28 April 2018). Due to the large number of records available for this species (> 50 000), we restricted our search to preserved specimens with geographic coordinates and that were collected after 1950. We also downloaded fossil records for O. princeps from the Neotoma Paleoecology Database to calibrate niche models according to the experimental design (see below, Williams et al. 2018) . We only included five records spanning an interval between 25 and 14 kbp that includes the maxima ice-sheet extent until the onset of deglaciation of the Western Hemisphere (<https://apps.neotomadb.org/explorer>, downloaded on 28 April 2018).

To reduce problems associated with spatial sampling bias, we spatially thinned our original datasets using the 'spThin' package in R to ensure that no two localities were within a given distance of one another (Aiello-Lammens et al. 2015). We used filtered datasets at 10, 20, and 30 km to assess the potential effect of spatial bias and alternative scenarios of high to low sample sizes on the estimation of the niche (see Data accessibility). As potential niche predictors, we used six bioclimatic variables that reflect aspects of temperature and precipitation and represent surrogates for factors limiting the distribution of cold-adapted species: BIO 02 (mean diurnal range), BIO 03 (isothermality), BIO 05 (max temperature of warmest month), BIO 06 (min temperature of coldest month), BIO 13 (precipitation of wettest month), and BIO 14 (precipitation of driest month). We delimited the area to calibrate and project models by drawing a 2.5° circular buffer around the localities before thinning. Given its extremely limited dispersal ability (Smith 1974) , we consider this area as a reasonable hypothesis of the accessible region via dispersal that minimize the inclusion of regions to which this species does not have access to (Barve et al. 2011 , Kubiak et al. 2017 .

We ensured a full representation of environments available for the species for model calibration by including all pixels within the delimited study area (i.e. 210 165 pixels, rather than the random sample of 10 000 pixels that Maxent uses by default). By doing this, we avoided artifactual truncation that can result from inadequate representation of the environmental background in a random sample (Guevara et al. 2018a) . To estimate the potential distributions during the LGM, we used the general circulation model from the Community Climate System Model (CCSM3; Collins et al. 2006) . We downloaded all current and LGM climate date at a spatial resolution of 2.5 min from the WorldClim dataset (Hijmans et al. 2005 ; <https://worldclim.org>). Importantly, we kept the same input data in our two experiments (see below) to reduce the contribution of confounding variables on the effect of restricted background datasets to calibrate models and transfer it into LGM conditions. In addition, it is not our objective to focus on the spatial variation that could be caused by the use of different general circulation models (Guevara et al. 2018b ).

To evaluate the effect of restricting the range of environmental conditions over which niche models are calibrated and transferred to LGM conditions, we performed two sets of experiments according to the following protocol. In Experiment 1 (hereafter, E1) we calibrated models in the context of only present-day climate conditions, which is the most common practice in Maxent. We then tested whether choosing an appropriate extrapolation method can improve geographic predictions onto LGM conditions by comparing two extrapolations methods available in Maxent (clamping versus unconstrained). In Experiment 2 (E2) we calibrated models using both present-day and LGM conditions associated with the background points, which is a variant of the multi-temporal calibration approach (Nogués-Bravo 2009) . For presence data, we also used the five fossil localities. Here we did not use pooled niches, but we calibrated single niche models using the environmental values of both the present and those that presumably existed during the LGM according to the CCSM scenario, which we call cross-time environmental background. Hence, each background point within the calibration area has two environmental values, one from current climate conditions and another from the climate during the LGM. In E2, we excluded background points from inaccessible areas that were covered by glaciers during the LGM (Supplementary material Appendix 1 Fig. A1 ). In E2 we also compared two extrapolation methods available in Maxent. In order to use the same background points in each experiment, we used the 'samples with data' (SWD) format (see tutorial in Maxent; Phillips 2017). As part of Maxent runs, we also obtained the multivariate environmental similarity surface (MESS) to indicate areas where non-analog conditions occur with respect to the conditions used in the calibration of the model and quantified the percentage of area with non-analogous conditions. MESS also provided information about which variable is driving this difference, which can be mapped as the most dissimilar variable (MoD) at any given pixel (Elith et al. 2010) .

We selected specific model settings for the three filtered datasets of the American pika approximating optimal levels of complexity using a wide variety of different combinations of feature classes (Linear; Quadratic; Linear and Quadratic; Hinge; Linear, Quadratic, and Hinge) and regularization multipliers (1.0-3.0 with 0.5 intervals) using the 'ENMeval' package in R (Muscarella et al. 2014) . This led to a total of 12 unique combinations of feature classes and regularization multipliers for each filtered dataset. We applied a spatial block approach to data partitioning in order to yield model evaluation statistics, which is especially relevant in cross-time model transfer (Roberts et al. 2017) . Optimal settings were selected based on the model with the lowest AICc (Akaike information criterion corrected for small sample sizes; Warren and Seifert 2011), but we also inspected thresholddependent (omission rate for testing points, or OR10, using a threshold set by the 10% training omission rate) and threshold-independent (AUC for testing points, or AUCtest, and the difference between calibration and evaluation AUC, AUCdiff) evaluation statistics to validate performing in terms of overfitting and discrimination, respectively. It is important to mention that, for demonstration and comparison purposes, we performed this model evaluation procedure for E1 only and used the same optimal settings for E2.

We made final models in the maxent.jar software ver. 3.4.3k (Phillips et al. 2006 ) using all filtered localities for the optimal settings previously identified. We report the logistic output of niche models. To display final maps, we preserved suitability values in the original continuous format above the 10th percentile training presence threshold (10th PTPT), which excludes the 10 percent of the training localities with the lowest suitability values.

The differences in the number of background values used to determine the Maxent distribution between the two experiments hinders a fair evaluation by comparing the two models statistically (E1 = 210 165 background values; E2 = 352 000 background values). We therefore based our model output evaluation mainly on qualitative assessment of response curves and the reconstructed geographical distributions, following previous knowledge of natural history of the species and of climatic and paleoecological evidence of the regions. We also quantitatively compared the overlap in reconstructed potential distributions using the Schoener's D metric in ENMTools (Warren et al. 2010) , which ranges from 0 (no overlap) to 1 (full overlap). To facilitate the interpretation of niche overlap values we used the following classes (Rödder and Engler 2011) : no or very limited overlap (0-0.2), low overlap (0.2-0.4), moderate overlap (0.4-0.6), high overlap (0.6-0.8), and very high overlap (0.8-1.0). Finally, we generated smoothed density representations of scatterplots through a kernel density estimate to show how suitability varies between experiments with respect to elevation using 'ggplot2' (Wickham and Chang 2008) .
body_text.section: Evaluation of model credibility between experiments

body_text.text: Data available from the Dryad Digital Repository: <https:// doi.org/10.5061/dryad.3bd5rr4> (Guevara and León-Paniag 2019) .

Spatial thinning reduced the original dataset from 2410 to 190, 154, and 133 localities using the distance of 10, 20, and 30 km, respectively. Threshold-dependent and threshold-independent evaluation statistics yielded clear trends regarding feature classes and regularization multipliers, irrespective of the filtered dataset used to calibrate the models (i.e. simple feature classes and low regularization multipliers). Geographic predictions were also highly similar among filtered datasets (Supplementary material Appendix 1 Table A1-A5). For this reason, we decided to discuss the resulting model from the database filtered at 10 km and calibrated using Linear and Quadratic features classes and regularization multiplier held at 1.0, which indicated high model performance in terms of overfitting and discrimination in comparison with the rest of the models evaluated (AUCtest = 0.895; AUCdiff = 0.035; OR10 = 0.137, Supplementary material Appendix 1 Table  A1 ). Estimates of relative importance of the environmental variables indicated that the maximum temperature of the warmest month (BIO 05) was the most important variable in both experiments.
body_text.section: Datasets, model selection and non-analog conditions

body_text.text: The MESS comparisons between calibration and projection regions indicated that, when models were calibrated using only present-day climates, large extents presented nonanalogous conditions during the LGM, specially for the maximum temperature of warmest month (BIO 05) and the minimum temperature of coldest month (BIO 06). Nonanalog conditions were located mainly at high latitudes and along the Rocky Mountains (Fig. 2a) . In contrast, using both present-day and LGM climates conditions pooled together as background considerably reduced the presence of nonanalogous conditions and the required degree of model extrapolation (Fig. 2b) .
body_text.section: Datasets, model selection and non-analog conditions

body_text.text: The model calibrated using only present-day climates estimated a current potential distribution consistent with the known distribution of the American pika, suggesting that it mainly occupies cold and moist habitats throughout the Sierra Nevada, Cascade Range, and Northern and Southern Rocky Mountains (Fig. 3a) . Estimates of suitability under LGM conditions varied considerably between the two extrapolation methods, but showing relatively high overlap ( Fig. 4a-b ; D = 0.661). Clamping predicted a considerably larger geographic extent of suitable areas during the LGM than unconstrained extrapolation (Fig. 4a ). Contrary to unconstrained extrapolation, clamping indicated as highly suitable the region that was covered by the Laurentide ice sheet during the coldest period of the LGM and assigned high suitability values to mountainous regions that suffered the expansion of alpine glaciers, such as the Northern Rocky Mountains. Clamping also suggested the existence of a large corridor between the Cascade Range and Northern Rocky Mountains, while unconstrained extrapolation indicated unsuitability for the Northern Rocky Mountains. Differences between extrapolation methods were also evident with respect to elevational shifts during the LGM. Clamping predicted more pixels between 500 and 2000 m, or even above 2000 m as highly suitable compared to predictions using unconstrained extrapolation ( Fig. 4d-e ).

The model calibrated using both present-day and LGM conditions as background was also largely consistent with the current known distribution of O. princeps, as observed in E1, but there was a more widespread prediction in areas at lower elevations and high latitude (Fig. 3b) . In contrast to models calibrated with present-day climates, LGM potential distributions here showed that pika populations were found at lower latitudes, far south of the lower limit of the Laurentide ice sheet, with no differences between extrapolation methods according to the niche overlap analysis (D = 0.999, Fig. 4c ). Using a cross-time environmental background also contributed to assigning low or null suitability values to mountainous regions that expanded their alpine glaciers during the LGM (Fig. 4c, f ) , such as the Northern Rocky Mountains and almost the entire range of the Sierra Nevada. Overall, E2 allowed more realistic estimations of potential distributions under LGM conditions.

Our results show that the existing environmental space that is represented across the model calibration area causes challenges in the estimation of niches and distributions derived from presence-background/pseudoabsences data (Broennimann and Guisan 2008, Owens et al. 2013) . Our simplified scenario included six climate variables, but still showed the challenge of modeling niches and geographic distributions. It is worth mentioning the importance of understanding the degree of causality of different sets of predictor variables and how correlations between variables can change over time, an issue that was not addressed here. In our study system, the niche was under-characterized since the cold and high elevation environments were no longer present in the current geography, leading to complications when the model was used to estimate the potential distribution under LGM conditions (Fig. 4) .

When it comes to model extrapolation, it is important to know how the fitted responses curves look at the extremes of the background values (Thuiller et al. 2004 , Elith et al. 2010 . Model transfer onto LGM climates can be improved substantially by visual inspection of the modeled response curves, allowing better-informed decisions about the best extrapolation method (Guevara et al. 2018a) . However, here this did not guarantee biologically realistic predictions under glacial conditions. According to what we now know about the Pleistocene history in North America, the geographic predictions for Ochotona princeps were remarkably implausible when clamping was enforced as the extrapolation method (which is the default setting in Maxent). These results intuitively suggest that differences due to extrapolation methods will be more strongly accentuated by the amount of the study area which has non-analogous conditions (Guevara et al. 2018b) . The comparison between extrapolation methods is an issue that should draw attention, and more comparative analyses are needed in order to arrive at any generalities about which method is better. We suggest carrying out such a comparison using species for which there is good knowledge about range shifts throughout the Quaternary (Nogués-Bravo 2009) .

Defining the area and, consequently, the range of environmental conditions where the models are calibrated is one of the most daunting challenges in presencebackground/pseudoabsences techniques (Elith et al. 2010) . Modifying the calibration area has an effect on the estimated response curves and variable importance in the models (VanDerWal et al. 2008 , Merow et al. 2013 . A widely used strategy is to sample the environmental background within the area that has been accessible for the species via dispersal over relevant time periods. For many species that are the subject of biogeographical studies, this relevant time period ranges from the LGM through the Pleistocene/Holocene transition, up to the present (Barve et al. 2011) . We agree with this strategy; however, given that niche models are built in environmental space, we consider that the background dataset should be chosen in the context of the environmental conditions in which species may occur, especially if the model is to be used to project past potential distributions. We then suggest that the background-pseudoabsence dataset should contain all the environments that have been presumably sampled by the species within the area that has accessible for the species via dispersal over relevant time periods, as a modification to the proposal by Barve et al. (2011) . Other climate snapshots besides the LGM should therefore be included in the model calibration to broaden the possibility of alternative climatic conditions across the evolutionary history of the species.

Using present-day and LGM climates pooled together to calibrate niche models in presence-background techniques clearly modifies the conceptual model as follow, which makes assumptions that are difficult to meet and corroborate, creating a challenge for model evaluation (Augusiak et al. 2014) . First, background values sampled from LGM climates assume that more cold habitats were sampled by the species and were environmentally unsuitable, potentially causing a false negative signal (Anderson and Raza 2010) . Detailed information about the focal species' physiology could help validate these assumptions in order to enrich our conceptual model. Ochotona princeps, for example, is particularly vulnerable to acute cold stress, which is an important driver of local extinction or extirpation (Beever et al. 2010) . Then, even cold-adapted species may be physiologically stressed by cold temperatures, making it unlikely that they have survived in extremely cold conditions imposed by the LGM. Second, for species with a null or insufficient fossil record, it is certainly difficult to corroborate the presence of the species in an area over the Quaternary. Despite these potential drawbacks, model calibration in the context of both modern and past climates should be considered to reduce the effect of niche truncation and lead to more realistic predictions of distributional changes (Nogués-Bravo 2009 , Davis et al. 2014 ). Figure 5 . Response curves for the most important variable for the American pika Ochotona princeps, models based on percent contribution and permutation importance (BIO 05, maximum temperature of warmest month in °C). In E1 (a-b), the response curve was truncated at 6°C, while in E2 (c) model calibration using present-day and LGM climates captured the whole of the response curve, allowing more credible estimations. The grey zone represents non-analog conditions, where the prediction depends on the extrapolation method chosen by the Maxent user ((a) clamping; (b) unconstrained). Note also how the shape of modeled response curves depend on the environmental background used in model calibration, as noted in Elith et al. (2010) .

An alternative solution to increasing the range of environmental conditions to calibrate niche models is expanding the calibration area to allow more environments to be sampled and used as background. However, this solution can violate assumptions of the conceptual model with regard to dispersal limitations of the species and the sampling efforts by researchers (Anderson and Raza 2010, Barve et al. 2011 ), so we do not recommend this solution. Instead, we advocate including all the environments that have been available within the accessible area to be used in the model calibration.

In the case of reconstructing distributions during the LGM, we see a major problem when trying to characterize niches using only present-day climates for species living on mountaintops due to the limited availability of cold environments often encountered due to geographic constraint. For example, insufficient sampling of cold environments across the calibration area of O. princeps altered and truncated the modeled response curves and seriously complicated geographical predictions towards more extreme cold conditions (Fig. 5 ). In these cases, exploratory data analyses should be performed before modeling to visualize if there are poorly-represented environments within the calibration area (Owens et al. 2013) .

We alert model developers and users to the possibility of obtaining implausible potential distributions due to restricted background or pseudoabsence datasets (Thuiller et al. 2004) . In this sense, we must pay careful attention to the model output corroboration within the modeling cycle (Augusiak et al. 2014) . Additional qualitative data or known patterns should be used whenever they are available to evaluate the model's credibility. Genetic and paleoecological evidence provide independent data against which to compare model outputs (Collevatti et al. 2013) . Knowledge about species' physiological limits are necessary to gain a more robust understanding of the fundamental niche of the species and therefore ensure the transferability of niche models across time and space. However, for most non-model organisms we need to approximate these physiological limits through correlative techniques, such as ecological niche modeling. We therefore need to improve existing tools and strategies or create new ones to generate more realistic models of species' responses to changing environments, leading to more useful biogeographic hypotheses.

FIGREF0.text: Map showing the occurrence data (black points) and calibration region (buffer around occurrences) used to estimate potential distribution of the American pika Ochotona princeps, in North America. Names of main physiographic features mentioned in the text are included.

FIGREF1.text: The most dissimilar variable (MoD) map showing areas that exhibit conditions outside the range present in calibration dataset during the Last Glacial Maximum based on (a) present-day climate conditions and (b) both present-day and Last Glacial conditions as background. Predictions in these areas should be treated with caution, especially if the most dissimilar variable is relevant in the prediction in those areas. Note how using both present-day and LGM (b) conditions as part of the same background in E2 largely reduces the required degree of extrapolation.

FIGREF2.text: Current projections of Maxent models for the American pika Ochotona princeps in North America, using (a) present-day climate conditions and (b) both present-day and Last Glacial conditions as background to calibrate the niche models. White dots are occurrences for the American pika. Redder colors indicate higher suitability.

FIGREF3.text: Reconstructed potential distribution during the Last Glacial Maximum (based on the CCSM scenario) for the American pika Ochotona princeps, in North America using (a-b) present-day climate conditions and (c) both present-day and Last Glacial conditions as background to calibrate the niche models. Panels (a) and (b) illustrate the differences in the geographic prediction due to de use of different extrapolation methods when there are non-analogous conditions ((a) clamping; (b) unconstrained). Redder colors indicate higher suitability. Smoothed density representations of scatterplots show how suitability varies with elevation between experiments and extrapolation methods ((a) represented in (d); (b) represented in (e); (c) represented in (f )).
